sn56.47:4.1: “Mendicants, suppose a person was to throw a yoke with a single hole into the ocean.
sn56.47:4.2: And there was a one-eyed turtle
sn56.47:4.3: who popped up once every hundred years.
sn56.47:4.4: What do you think, mendicants? Would that one-eyed turtle, popping up once every hundred years, still poke its neck through the hole in that yoke?”
sn56.47:4.5: “Only after a very long time, sir, if ever.”
sn56.47:5.1: “That one-eyed turtle would poke its neck through the hole in that yoke sooner than a fool who has fallen to the underworld would be reborn as a human being, I say.
sn56.47:6.2: Because there there’s no principled or moral conduct, and no doing what is good and skillful.
sn56.47:6.3: There they just prey on each other, preying on the weak.
sn56.47:6.5: It’s because they haven’t seen the four noble truths.
sn56.47:6.7: The noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
sn56.47:7.1: That’s why you should practice meditation …”
